|Ship crew= |Ship EW=1 × 21-Gō early warning radar |Ship armament=*4 × [[14 cm/50 3rd Year Type naval gun]]s *2 × [[8 cm/40 3rd Year Type naval gun]]s *2 × [[Type 96 25 mm AT/AA Gun|Type 96 25 mm AA gun]]s *4 × [[13.2 mm Hotchkiss machine gun|Type 93 13 mm AA guns]] |Ship armour= }} |} {{nihongo|'''''Jingei'''''|迅鯨|Swift Whale}},<ref>Nelson. ''Japanese-English Character Dictionary''. pages 872, 984</ref> was the [[lead vessel]] of the {{sclass-|Jingei|submarine tender}}s operated by the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]], from the 1920s through [[World War II]]. She was the first purpose-built submarine tender in the Imperial Japanese Navy.<ref name= Jentsura >Jentsura, ''Warships of the Imperial Japanese Navy'', p. 237</ref>
==Background== Under the [[Eight-eight fleet]] plan, the Imperial Japanese Navy planned to acquire 100 submarines for long-distance scouting operations, which would also be used to conduct [[attrition warfare]] against any enemy fleet approaching Japan. ''Jingei'' was intended to serve as a [[flagship]] for the Submarine Division Commander and as a depot ship for the nine submarines in a submarine division.
Initially, ''Jingei'' was planned as a 14,500-ton vessel; however, her specifications were scaled down to 8,500-tons due to restrictions imposed by the [[Washington Naval Treaty]].
==Design== ''Jingei'' was built by [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries|Mitsubishi Yards]] in [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]], and the contractor was given an unusually free hand in her design. In order to keep costs to a minimum, the basic design of her hull was adapted from that of a standard civilian merchant vessel, of which Mitsubishi had considerable experience in building. Her coal/oil-fired boilers were taken from the cancelled [[Tosa-class battleship|''Tosa''-class]] battleship project. As Mitsubishi was also working on the {{sclass-|Katori|cruiser|2}}s at the same time, many design innovations that had been developed by Mitsubishi engineers were shared between the two classes, and as a result, the ''Katori''-class cruisers came bear a superficial resemblance to the ''Jingei''-class submarine tenders.
== Operational career == ''Jingei'' was laid down on 16 February 1922, launched on 4 May 1923 and completed on 30 August 1923.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://homepage2.nifty.com/nishidah/e/stc0850.htm | title= Jingei class submarine depot ships| last= Nishidah | first= Hiroshi| year= 2002 | work= Materials of the Imperial Japanese Navy | publisher= }}</ref> Initially assigned to the [[Yokosuka Naval District]], she replaced the aging {{ship|Japanese submarine tender|Karasaki||2}}.
Following the [[Tomozuru Incident|''Tomozuru'' Incident]] of 13 March 1934, all ships of the Japanese Navy were subject to inspection and renovation of design flaws that would put the ship in danger of capsizing. Renovations were begun on ''Jingei'' in November 1934 at the [[Sasebo Naval Arsenal]] to equip the vessel with new ballast tanks and bilge pumps. As the ''Jingei''-class submarine tenders were unable to support the new {{sclass-|Kaidai|submarine|2}}s, they were reassigned to the Training Fleet around this time, and their duties as submarine tenders were taken up by the new {{sclass-|Kuma|cruiser|2}}s.
After the [[Marco Polo Bridge Incident]] of 7 July 1937, ''Jingei'' was part of the escort for the convoys transporting the [[10th Division (Imperial Japanese Army)|IJA 10th Division]] to northern China, but took no further combat role in the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]].<ref name=Combined>[http://www.combinedfleet.com/Jingei_t.htm IJN ''Jingei'': Tabular Record of Movement]</ref>
On 15 November 1940, in preparation for the coming conflict with the United States, both ''Jingei''-class ships were returned to active combat status, replacing [[Japanese aircraft carrier Zuihō|''Takasaki'']] and [[Japanese aircraft carrier Shōhō|''Tsuruguzaki'']], which were then converted to [[aircraft carrier]]s. ''Jingei'' was assigned as [[flagship]] of the 7th Submarine Squadron, [[4th Fleet (Imperial Japanese Navy)|IJN 4th Fleet]], and was equipped with an [[Kawanishi E7K]]2 reconnaissance floatplane.
Following the start of the [[Pacific War]], ''Jingei'' participated in the [[Battle of Wake Island]] from 8–10 December 1941. On 29 December 1941, she went to the rescue of the submarine {{Jsub|Ro-60||2}}, which had run aground on a reef north of [[Kwajalein]]. The submarine was a total loss, but all of her crewmen were rescued.<ref name=Combined/>
On 14 July 1942, ''Jingei'' was reassigned to the [[8th Fleet (Imperial Japanese Navy)|IJN 8th Fleet]] based in [[Rabaul]]. She was relieved by her [[sister ship]], {{ship|Japanese submarine tender|Chōgei||2}} on 7 November 1943, and was withdrawn back to Japan, arriving at [[Kure Naval District]] by the end of the month.
On 12 January 1943, ''Jingei'' was reassigned to Kure Naval District as a training vessel for the Kure Submarine Warfare School, where she remained for the remainder of the year. On 16 October 1943, she was sent to render assistance to the supply ship {{ship|Japanese food supply ship|Mamiya||2}}, which had been torpedoed off [[Chichijima]]. In December, she towed Hull 300 from Kure to [[Sasebo Naval Arsenal]] for conversion in the aircraft carrier {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Ibuki|1943|2}}.<ref name=Combined/><ref name=Combined/>
''Jingei'' returned to front-line combat status on 1 January 1944 as flagship of Submarine Squadron 41, based at Kure. In summer, her main guns were replaced with 18 [[Type 96 25 mm AT/AA Gun|Type 96 25-mm antiaircraft gun]]s. She subsequently made three roundtrips to [[Okinawa]] as a transport for supplies and reinforcements from 11 August through 18 September 1944. On her fourth mission to Okinawa, on 19 September 1944, she was torpedoed 80 miles northwest of [[Naha, Okinawa|Naha]] by {{USS|Scabbardfish|SS-397|6}}. She was towed to Okinawa and beached northwest of Naha. On 10 October 1944, the immobile ''Jingei'' was attacked by Allied aircraft of [[Fast Carrier Task Force|Task Force 38]] launched from {{USS|Hancock|CV-19|6}} and sank in shallow waters at {{coord|26|39|N|127|52|E}}, with the loss of 100 crewmen. ''Jingei'' officially struck from the [[navy list]] on 10 November 1944. In September 1952, she was refloated and towed to [[Tobata-ku, Kitakyūshū]], where her hulk was salvaged for scrap.<ref name=Combined/>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image: Two japanese Jingei-class submarine tenders.jpg|<center>With ''Chōgei'' 1924</center> Image: Jingei in action.jpg|<center>With Submarine I-5</center> Image: Japanese submarine tender Jingei.jpg|<center>With Submarine Flotilla 26 in 1927</center> Image: Japanese submarine tender Jingei 1937.jpg|<center>In 1937</center> </gallery>
